title: 108_hr5184
content: In fiscal year 2005, adjustments to sums authorized for highway programs shall be zero. Congress aims to align highway spending with revenues to minimize fluctuations and ensure uniform enforcement. Congress also supports fully guaranteed funding for highway programs. In fiscal year 2005, Congress supports fully guaranteed funding for highway programs, aiming for alignment with revenues to minimize fluctuations and ensure uniform enforcement. Congress emphasizes that in any multiyear law reauthorizing the Federal-aid highway program, obligation limitations should be equal to those authorized in the law. In fiscal year 2005, the mass transit category obligation limitation level should align with budget authority and obligation limitation authorizations for Federal Transit Administration programs in a multiyear reauthorization. SEC. 11. LEVEL OF OBLIGATION LIMITATIONS. In fiscal year 2005, the Highway Category is allocated $35,392,000,000, and the Mass Transit Category is allocated $7,265,000,000 under the Transportation Equity Act. Funds under this Act shall be deemed zero for section 110 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 12. Extension of authorization for use of trust funds for obligations under TEA-21. The Highway Trust Fund is amended to authorize payments under the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004, Part V, extending the authorization for use of trust funds for obligations under TEA-21. The Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004, Part V, amends the Mass transit account section of the Code by changing the date from October 1, 2004, to June 1, 2005, and adding a new subparagraph (I) for the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004, Part V. The Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004, Part V, makes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code by changing dates and striking certain paragraphs. The Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004, Part V amends the Internal Revenue Code by changing dates and striking specific paragraphs related to boat safety and alcohol fuel taxes. The Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004 amends the Internal Revenue Code by changing dates for certain taxes not transferred to the Highway Trust Fund. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, except for transfers to the highway trust fund which apply to taxes imposed after September 30, 2003. Additionally, a temporary rule regarding adjustments is in place until May 31, 2005 for estimating receipts of the Highway Trust Fund. The Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004 extends expiring provisions related to appropriations and tax rates for the Highway Trust Fund until the end of a 24-month period. Additionally, the apportionment of Highway Trust Funds for Fiscal Year 2004 is addressed in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 9503(d)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 does not apply to the apportionment of amounts from the Highway Trust Fund for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2004. SEC. 13. Extension of highway programs through end of fiscal year 2004. The text chunk discusses amendments to various transportation acts, including changes to authorization of contract authority and limitations on obligations. For fiscal year 2004, the Secretary will distribute obligation limitation for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs according to section 110 of the Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 2004, with specified exceptions. The Secretary will distribute funding for programs based on the authorized amounts in various Acts, or a percentage of funding provided in the Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 2004. The Secretary will set aside $1,952,480,770 for high priority projects as authorized by the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2004. Certain sections of the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2003 are repealed. SEC. 14. HIGH PRIORITY PROJECTS PROGRAM. Authorization of Appropriations for the high priority projects program under title 23, United States Code, is amended for fiscal year 2004 and the period of October 1, 2004, through May 31, 2005. Allocation percentages are also adjusted accordingly. The authorization of appropriations for the high priority projects program under title 23, United States Code, is amended by adjusting allocation percentages for fiscal years 2004 to 2009. The federal share section is also amended to remove certain language. The text chunk discusses amendments to various sections of title 23, United States Code, including changes to advance construction, availability of obligation limitation, and federal-state relationship. Amendments include updating references to different acts and inserting new provisions related to transportation projects. The text chunk discusses project authorizations for high priority projects under section 117 of title 23, United States Code, as outlined in H.R. 3550. The funds for these projects are available from the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century for fiscal year 2004.
